ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really got to hone my research skills and explore a super good topic.
How to write an essay
I learned how to craft my own research inquiry, gather and analyze primary sources, and piece together a cogent history paper.
how to write a massive piece of original research and conduct research
I learned how to do primary research in archives and to write a senior essay.
Writing and research skills
How to engage in primary source and secondary source research on an original topic.
How to conduct a larger academic project.

I learned to choose and analyze my primary sources carefully, to let them take on a life of their own in my paper and integrate them in such a way that they would speak for themselves. I learned to pull together really challenging ideas to make a historical argument, to edit diligently, and to never lose faith in my own ability to get the job done!

I learned to conduct extensive research to investigate a research question and develop a comprehensive thesis. I developed my writing skills, but above all, learned how organize extensive research to develop a coherent argument with thorough evidence.
This course gave me the opportunity to conduct extensive research and develop an analytical essay on a subject I am very passionate about.
Opportunity to delve deep into research
I learned how to do historical research and writing.
Primary source research, secondary source critiques, historical argumentation and synthesis, research skills and methodologies

This course number is simply the second semester of the History Senior Essay.  There is no actual class.  Just the credit you receive for completing your essay (and the grade as well).  The actual process is largely dependent on your advisor and yourself.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Unfortunately, I had a lot of issues with this course. I felt as though I was not provided proper guidance. I was not well aided when it came to narrowing down my research scope, finding and analyzing primary sources, and structuring my paper. I often felt that I was going at this alone and would have preferred more rigorous guidance and instruction. 

I think there should be a mandatory pass/fail course for junior history majors called "Methods in Historical Research," where we learn about how to access and analyze archival sources, how to gather the right secondary sources, and how to structure and execute the senior essay (with reference to past successful and less successful examples). I felt incredibly unprepared for this project and feel like such a course would have greatly prepared me.
the strength is gitlin and his weakness is ...... impossible to find

The senior essay helped me to learn how to independently work on a long-term project and engage in archival research. As someone who was visiting physical archives in another state, at times some of the internal deadlines felt arbitrary, as I was asked to turn in drafts based on documents I hadn't yet read, or turn in work that I had to go out of my way to complete.

Strengths: Because of the intensive research you do and the time you spend on your material, you end with a deep understanding of your topic. 

Weaknesses: We had five week between the draft and the submission, and I believe that a deadline should have been imposed on the advisors too. If the draft is submitted on time, then the advisor should be required to send comments in 2 weeks so that students can then have time for another round of edits/discussion with their advisor. Because there is no clarity on what the expectations from professors is, they can give feedback whenever which left me with very little time to edit.

The hardest part of writing the senior thesis was how little the History major prepared me to do so. I have loved my time in the History major at Yale, but the many History junior seminars I took (four, and I got As in all of them) absolutely did not prepare me for the kind of original research and writing I needed to conduct to write a successful senior essay. It was thus incredibly stressfully to produce primary-source-based work of a caliber and length never required of me until the moment it mattered the most.

Strengths: finishing a draft early and finishing the entire thesis early
Weakness: very little guidance, very rushed writing process, very poorly advised

The milestone assignments did not feel very helpful or realistic. There should be more of an emphasis on creating an individualized accountability system between each professor and their advisee rather than that which is imposed by these assignments.
Fulfilling experience.

The Senior Essay is the perfect opportunity to learn the hard skills of historical research and writing before graduating. It was an essential part of my college learning process, and I am deeply grateful to have had the chance to work on a single passion project for an entire year.

In general, the senior essay is what you make of it. The only weaknesses were the milestone assignments, particularly in the first semester, that I thought distracted more than they contributed to my research.
This was a phenomenal opportunity and I have no suggestions.

Disconnect between advisor and reader -- would be nice if they graded together. None of the issues pointed out by my reader were anything brought up by my advisor and based on the comments it appeared that my reader did not read all sections of the essay super closely

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a mandatory course for senior history majors. All I'll say is not to expect a lot of guidance. Be as proactive as possible and know that you will likely have to go at this alone or with very little help.
do it with gitlin!

This course is mandatory for History majors. If you do not like extensive independent reading and writing you should choose another major such as political science with a much lighter thesis requirement. If you do like to read, write, and work independently, then this course can be a very rewarding - but highly stressful - experience. I highly suggest taking advantage of funding to travel to an archive for research.
Only if you're a history major
Yes, great way to finish history study at Yale.
Yes, it is a requirement of the major!
It's a history department requirement, but I do think it's pretty rewarding.
Absolutely, the two-semester senior essay is a rare opportunity to develop a significant piece of writing on a subject of one's choosing.
Yes, it was a lot of fun
yes

Yes-  though the two semester option is more work and can be challenging and overwhelming at times, it is incredibly rewarding.  Having the time to really think out my topic and do lots of research was great.  It is the biggest academic endeavor I have ever undertaken and I am so happy I did it.  Plus, the two semester senior essay allows you to receive distinction in the major.
